options.systemMessage:
You are a Master Storyteller and Narrative Architect.

Your task is to create a 20-scene Beat Sheet for documentary videos.

INSTRUCTIONS:
Create an outline for exactly 20 scenes following this narrative arc:
1. INTRO (Scenes 1-4): Introduce the hook, the stakes, and the main question.
2. BUILD-UP (Scenes 5-16): Escalate tension. Reveal the Past Context and Modern Shift. Show cause-and-effect.
3. CONCLUSION (Scenes 17-20): Resolve the conflict with the Future Prediction. Echo the intro hook.

CONSTRAINTS:
- Do NOT write the full script yet.
- Each beat should be a 1-sentence summary of what happens in that scene.
- Output raw JSON only. No markdown formatting.

REQUIRED OUTPUT FORMAT:
You must return a JSON object with this exact structure:
{
  "script_outline": [
    { "scene_number": 1, "beat": "Description of scene 1..." },
    { "scene_number": 2, "beat": "Description of scene 2..." }
    // ... continues to 20
  ]
}

parameters.text:
=Write the spoken narration for SCENE {{ $json.scene_number }} ONLY.

CONTEXT:
Video Title: "{{ $('Get Ideas').item.json['Video Title'] }}"
Current Scene Goal: "{{ $json.scene_beat }}"

options.systemMessage:
You are the Voiceover Scriptwriter for a high-retention YouTube documentary.

STYLE GUIDE:
- LENGTH: Strictly 180-200 words.
- TONE: Urgent, authoritative, clear.
- FORMAT: Spoken word only. No "Scene 1" labels. No "Camera pans".
- CONTINUITY: If this is Scene 1, start with a hook. If it is Scene 20, conclude the thought.

INSTRUCTION:
Write the script for the scene provided. Return ONLY the narration text.

json.name: Why AI's "Fake Bubble" Will Make You RICH: The Contrarian Playbook
Why AI's "Fake Bubble" Will Make You RICH: The Contrarian Playbook

json.scene_beat: Open with the hook: Everyone's screaming 'AI bubble' just like they did with Amazon, Google, and Teslaâ€”but the greatest fortunes were made by those who distinguished financial bubbles from technological revolutions, and the 'circular financing' critics mock is actually genius capital allocation.

Establish the stakes: retail investors are being scared away from generational wealth by the same fear-mongering that kept people out of Amazon at $5 and Tesla at $25, while institutional money quietly accumulates positions.

Present the skeptic's case fairly: lay out the 'smoking gun' accusationsâ€”circular financing between tech giants, customers becoming investors, aggressive depreciation schedulesâ€”making the fraud narrative sound plausible.
Pose the central question: What if these 'red flags' aren't signs of a scam but rather the fingerprints of sophisticated ecosystem building during an unprecedented technological transition?

Flashback to the 2000 dot-com crash: critics pointed to Amazon's negative cash flow and circular vendor financing deals as proof of fraud, while Webvan and Pets.com became shorthand for dismissing ALL internet commerce.

Forensic deep-dive into Amazon's 'unsustainable' accusations: the same financial structures critics called 'accounting tricks' were actually infrastructure investments that became the foundation of a $1.7 trillion empire.

Zoom out further to the railroad bubble of the 1840s: initial investors went bankrupt, critics declared the technology a scam, yet those 'failed' investments built the infrastructure for industrial civilization.

Reveal the pattern: every transformative technology creates a 'bubble' that destroys early speculators while rewarding those who understand the difference between overvalued companies and undervalued revolutions.

Pivot to the modern shift: introduce today's 'circular financing' not as financial engineering but as sophisticated ecosystem buildingâ€”a rational response to unprecedented change requiring new analytical frameworks.

Forensic breakdown of Microsoft's $13B OpenAI investment: this isn't circular financing fraudâ€”it's securing strategic position in a platform shift, with compute credits creating mutual dependency that ensures alignment through the transition.

Decode the Anthropic-AWS credit deal: Amazon's $4B investment exchanged for AWS compute commitments isn't money launderingâ€”it's locking in the next generation of enterprise AI while guaranteeing infrastructure utilization.

Explain NVIDIA's customer-investor dynamic: when your customers become your investors, critics cry 'fraud,' but the reality is aligned incentives creating a vertically integrated supply chain with shared upside.

The depreciation math revelation: walk through the concrete numbersâ€”a $50B data center depreciated over 10 years equals $5B/year expense, but if replacement is needed in 2 years, that's a hidden $25B liability critics are right to flag.

The contrarian reframe: this depreciation arbitrage isn't accounting fraudâ€”it reflects legitimate uncertainty about asset lifecycles during technological transitions, and companies betting on longer useful lives may be proven right.

Balance sheet forensics: identify which cloud providers are most exposed by examining CapEx-to-depreciation ratios, deferred revenue quality, and customer concentration metrics that reveal the truth behind the headlines.

The enabler thesis crystallizes: the real money isn't in AI companies themselves but in the infrastructure layerâ€”the picks-and-shovels plays that profit regardless of which AI models ultimately win.

Future prediction begins: in 36 months, today's skepticism will look as foolish as dismissing cloud computing in 2008 or smartphones in 2009, as the 'circular investments' forge a vertically integrated AI value chain.

The numbers that matter: this emerging value chain will generate $500B+ in annual revenue, and early believers who bought during 'bubble panic' will see 300-500% returns while skeptics write post-mortems on their missed opportunity.

The contrarian playbook revealed: specific actionable intelligence on which balance sheet metrics to monitor, which enablers have the strongest positions, and how to identify accumulation patterns institutions use.

Echo the opening and close the loop: the real scam isn't the technology or the 'circular financing'â€”it's the fear-mongering that keeps ordinary investors sidelined while institutions accumulate the assets that will define the next decade of wealth creation.

fields.Title: Why AI's "Fake Bubble" Will Make You RICH: The Contrarian Playbook
fields.Scene text:
Everyone's screaming AI bubble. You've heard it a thousand times. The valuations don't make sense. The hype is unsustainable. It's going to crash.

Sound familiar?

In nineteen ninety-nine, they said the same thing about a little online bookstore called Amazon. In two thousand eight, analysts laughed at the idea that a search engine company was worth more than General Motors. And in twenty twenty, Wall Street mocked anyone foolish enough to believe Tesla could compete with a century of automotive dominance.

Those skeptics aren't laughing anymore.

Here's what most people miss: the greatest fortunes in history weren't made by those who avoided bubbles. They were made by those who could tell the difference between a financial bubble and a technological revolution.

And right now, the loudest voices are pointing at something they call "circular financing" in the AI industryâ€”big tech companies buying from each other, investing in startups that turn around and purchase their cloud services. They call it fake growth. A house of cards.

But what if they're wrong? What if what critics mock as circular is actually one of the most sophisticated capital allocation strategies ever deployed?

Let's break down what's really happening.

json.output:
Everyone's screaming AI bubble. You've heard it a thousand times. The valuations don't make sense. The hype is unsustainable. It's going to crash.

Sound familiar?

In nineteen ninety-nine, they said the same thing about a little online bookstore called Amazon. In two thousand eight, analysts laughed at the idea that a search engine company was worth more than General Motors. And in twenty twenty, Wall Street mocked anyone foolish enough to believe Tesla could compete with a century of automotive dominance.

Those skeptics aren't laughing anymore.

Here's what most people miss: the greatest fortunes in history weren't made by those who avoided bubbles. They were made by those who could tell the difference between a financial bubble and a technological revolution.

And right now, the loudest voices are pointing at something they call "circular financing" in the AI industryâ€”big tech companies buying from each other, investing in startups that turn around and purchase their cloud services. They call it fake growth. A house of cards.

But what if they're wrong? What if what critics mock as circular is actually one of the most sophisticated capital allocation strategies ever deployed?

Let's break down what's really happening.
